p.mixed-citation: A further possible exception concerns British Airways in the 1980s where new entrants might have introduced competition on certain routes. In general, though, competition between airlines remained highly regulated.

In particular, that there are constant returns to scale and that the firm faces competitive factor and product markets. Also, that the firm is in equilibrium with factors of production being paid the value of their marginal products. Consequently, factor payments exhaust the firm's total revenue.
Regulation also creates complications. The measurement of TFP will be affected by a regulatory rule of the RPI-Jf% variety. This did not affect any of our organisations over the period studied.

A formal statement of the model and full details of the data and input and output price indices used can be obtained from the authors. For all organisations, output and expenditure data were extracted from annual reports and accounts and in certain cases internal working papers.
In all cases the dates refer to accounting year ends. For example, for HMSO 1977-80 refers to the accounting years year ending 31 March 1977 to 31 March 1980.
